title: Windows 1.0
overview: Microsoft releases Windows 1.0, a graphical shell running on top of MS-DOS, marking the company’s entry into graphical user interfaces.

title: Windows 2.0
overview: Windows 2.0 introduces overlapping windows, keyboard shortcuts, and improved memory management, gaining traction in offices.

title: Windows 3.0
overview: Windows 3.0 becomes Microsoft’s first commercial success, offering a robust GUI, program manager, and better multitasking.

title: Windows 3.1
overview: Windows 3.1 improves stability, TrueType fonts, and multimedia support, becoming a dominant desktop platform in enterprises.

title: Windows NT 3.1
overview: Microsoft introduces Windows NT 3.1, a new 32-bit OS built for enterprise use with advanced networking and security features.

title: Windows 95
overview: Windows 95 launches with a Start Menu, taskbar, and built-in TCP/IP support, driving massive PC adoption worldwide.

title: Windows 98
overview: Windows 98 enhances USB support, Internet Explorer integration, and Plug and Play hardware support, dominating consumer PCs.

title: Windows 2000
overview: Windows 2000 combines NT stability with Windows usability, introducing Active Directory and becoming an enterprise standard.

title: Windows ME
overview: Windows Millennium Edition targets home users, adding System Restore and multimedia features but criticized for instability.

title: Windows XP
overview: Windows XP unifies consumer and enterprise lines, becoming Microsoft’s most iconic OS with widespread adoption for over a decade.

title: Windows Vista
overview: Vista introduces Aero Glass UI and UAC security, but suffers from performance and compatibility issues.

title: Windows 7
overview: Windows 7 fixes Vista’s shortcomings with better performance, stability, and a refined UI, becoming highly popular.

title: Windows 8
overview: Windows 8 introduces the Metro UI with tiles for touchscreens, but alienates many desktop users due to loss of Start Menu.

title: Windows 8.1
overview: Windows 8.1 restores the Start button and refines Metro UI, addressing criticism from desktop users.

title: Windows 10
overview: Windows 10 blends desktop and modern UI, introduces Edge browser and Cortana, and becomes Microsoft’s long-term service OS.

title: Windows 11
overview: Windows 11 refreshes the UI with a centered taskbar, Snap layouts, improved gaming, and tighter integration with cloud services.
